titlestmt.titleproper: Harding Black collection, Inclusive: 1910-2014, undated, Bulk: 1954-1998, undated

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The Harding Black collection contains material on the life, legacy, and career of noted ceramic expert Harding Black. Harding Black's greatest contribution to the ceramics community was his glaze research, which included extensive work to recreate ancient Chinese glazes from the Song and Tang dynasties.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Harding Black was born in 1912, near Aransas Pass, Texas. He became interested in ceramics while excavating ancient American Indian mounds near Big Bend, Texas, and was taught to throw clay by his colleague, Rudolf Staffel.

In 1933, Black set up his first studio in a streetcar, behind the Witte Museum, in San Antonio. He taught ceramics classes for children as part of the Witte Museum's series of children's classes. In the late 1930s, Black became involved with the Works Progress Administration (WPA). During the 1940s and 1950s, his work began to be exhibited in major venues, and in 1953, his groundbreaking work on copper-red glazes was featured the January issue of Ceramics Monthly.

Harding Black is best known for his glaze research, primarily in ancient Chinese and Scandinavian glazes. He kept meticulous records of his glaze tests, and it is possible to match the glaze codes found on many of his ceramic test pieces to glaze formulas recorded in his notebooks. As noted in the 1998 exhibition catalog from the University of Dallas, “His discovery of methods which duplicate the elusive chun, flambe, oxblood, and oilspot glazes of ancient China’s Ming and [Song] dynasties fundamentally altered the landscape of contemporary American ceramics.”

In 1989 Harding Black became acquainted with Baylor University ceramist Paul McCoy. The two artists developed a friendship that lasted the rest of Black's life. In 1995, Harding Black gave Baylor University his extensive collection of glaze research, in the form of thousands of test tiles, vases, and bowls, as well as volumes of glaze formulas and related notes.
Harding Black’s work continued to be exhibited and published into the early 2000s, including a retrospective at Baylor University in 1995. Harding Black died of respiratory failure on May 2, 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Harding Black collection begins in 1910 and ends in 2014. The bulk of the materials are from 1954-1998 . Both Subgroup I. Personal Papers and Subgroup II. Collected Papers are about the same size.

Subgroup I. Personal Papers includes Harding Black's glaze notebooks, firing logs, and other materials he created in his workshop. The most fragile of these materials have been digitized and the papers copies are restricted due to preservation concerns.

Subgroup II. Collected Papers includes materials created by the Curator of the Harding Black Collection and Archive, Professor Paul McCoy, as well as documents from the Baylor University Office of University Development and several avid Harding Black collectors.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to current processing, around half of the collection was in folders with titles and some arrangement. The majority of the over 500 volumes of books in the collection were transferred to the Texas Collection library or to the Baylor University Art Department. The collection is divided into two subgroups: Subgroup I. Personal Papers and Subgroup II. Collected Papers.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is restricted. Please see an archivist for details.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Portions of this collection are to be used only by members of Baylor University Office of University Development or Baylor University Art Department or by permission of said organizations. Parts of this collection that are open for research and contain records that were redacted for personal identifying information and other privacy concerns. This collection includes extremely fragile materials, which have been restricted for preservation purposes. Contact archivist for details.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Harding Black collection, Accession #3911, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Amanda Dietz, Josh Garland, and Paul Fisher. Released on 2015-06-21.

Pottery, American -- Texas -- San Antonio -- 20th century.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Subgroup I. Personal Papers contains materials created or collected by Harding Black, including his glaze code formulae, firing logs, as well as correspondence and printed publications. The first 3 boxes of the subgroup have been digitized due to the fragile nature of the materials and are also available through the Baylor University Libraries Digital Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Subgroup II. Collected Papers contains materials created or collected by Baylor University and avid Harding Black collectors. The subgroup includes substantial information about Baylor University Professor Paul McCoy's work on the Harding Black Collection and Archive, including correspondence with collectors, plans for development dinners, and proposals for possible use of the collection. The end of the subseries includes photographs of Harding Black's work and of Harding Black himself working in his San Antonio studio. There are also multiple oral histories conducted by Paul McCoy with Harding Black and other collectors.
